intro: Oxytropis aurea, commonly known as golden burro's tail, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its hairy, branched stems and small, yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid environments. Its seed pods are distinctive, containing numerous small, hard seeds that are dispersed by wind. Oxytropis aurea is often used in xeriscaping due to its low water requirements and ornamental value.
